utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Mmm, gentlemen, I put it to you, the worst tapioca pudding is better than the best pudding of any other flavour.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: First off, that is axiomatically wrong, because the best pudding is chocolate. Secondly, the organic structure of tapioca makes it a jiggling bowl of potential death. It is extracted from the plant…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, I’m thinking of growing a mustache.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Ah, no kidding! A Fu Man Chu? A handlebar pencil?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It is extracted from the plant…

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m not sure yet. You know, George Clooney has one now!

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Really? I once saw him shopping at Ralph’s. He was buying tequila.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, you’d think a guy like that would have some kind of booze lackey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Alright this is cruel, we better let him finish before his head explodes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Alright Sheldon, why is tapioca…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Tapioca is extracted from the root of the plant Manihot Esculenta. Due to a high concentration of cyanide it is poisonous in its raw form and lethal if prepared improperly.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Feel better now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It is also indigenous to Brazil, as is the Cocoa Bean, from which we get chocolate, the best pudding. And you promised you wouldn’t do that anymore!

utterance.speaker: Kripke (arriving)
utterance.content: Hey Hofstadter!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey Kripke.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Heard about your watest pwoton decay expewiment, twenty thousand data wuns and no statistically significant wesults. Vewy impwessive!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What a jerk.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Don’t feel bad Leonard, negative results are still results.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Even twenty thousand of ’em.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Alright, please don’t cheer me up anymore.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: C’mon, don’t let him get to you. It’s Kripke.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, he’s a ginormous knob.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s why he eats by himself, instead of sitting here at the cool table.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fo’ shizzle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hey it’s true, Kripke lacks the basic social skills that we take for granted, but he also controls the new open science grid computer that I need to use to run some simulations of structure formation in the early universe.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good luck getting time on it. The only people he lets use it are his friends.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well then, the solution is simple. I shall befriend him. Kripke!

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What’d you say of the idea of you and I becoming friends?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: I would say, I have no intewest in becoming your fwiend.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really? That seems rather short sighted, coming from someone who is generally considered altogether unlikable. Why don’t you take some time to reconsider?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Yeah, I’ll do that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well I think we’re off to a terrific start.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There you go. Now any e-mail from Wolowitz will go right into your spam folder.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thanks! I mean the e-mail doesn’t bother me as much as the vacation pictures of him in a bathing suit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I got the same one. And that’s not a bathing suit, it’s a tan line.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (on phone)
utterance.content: Hello. This is Sheldon Cooper. I’m leaving a message for Barry Kripke. Barry, It was pleasant seeing you today in the cafeteria. I saw that you purchased the chef’s salad. Apparently, you did not know that the chef’s salad is kitchen trickery, to utilize scrap meat. Nevertheless, I hope you enjoyed it. I’m following up on our pending friendship, and I look forward to hearing from you regarding its status. Sheldon Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What’s up with Ichabod?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh he’s trying to make a new friend.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh really? Well, good for him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, unless he’s makes one out of wood like Gepetto, I don’t think it’s gonna happen.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, how did you guys become friends?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There was a flier on the bulletin board at the university. Roommate wanted. Whistlers need not apply.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: And you moved in anyway?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I assumed he was joking. You’d be surprised how many particle physicists have a whimsical side.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, what about Howard and Raj, I mean how did you become friends with them?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know, how do carbon atoms form a benzene ring? Proximity and valence electrons.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well yeah, sure. When you put it that way. But it all worked out, right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I suppose. I do miss whistling though.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh come on, really?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: First warning.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (Knock, knock, knock)
utterance.content: Penny Penny Penny.This is for you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hello Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What is this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a questionnaire I devised. I’m having some difficulty bonding with a colleague at work, so I’m doing a little research to better understand why my current friends like me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes. Well, that is a good question. But is this really the best way to figure it out?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, I agree, the social sciences are largely hokum. But, short of putting electrodes in your brain and monitoring your response to my companionship, this is the best I can do.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, question 1. Rank the following aspects of Sheldon Cooper in order of appeal. Intelligence. Ruthless attention to hygiene. Playfulness. Java applet writing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I know, I may have started off with a fairly obvious one. You did an aspect of my most appealing trait, playfulness. Why don’t you just go ahead and write that number 1. I’m afraid you’re on your own for the rest. It should take you no more than 3 hours.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wait! How many questions are on this thing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Only 211. Don’t worry, in deference to you, I’ve kept them on a high school graduate reading level.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thanks pal.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You got it, buddy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon honey, did you ever consider making friends by being, I don’t know, pleasant?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well that’s certainly a thought-provoking hypothesis. May I suggest it as the topic for your essay.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Your questionnaire, very disappointing.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I answered every question Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You answered the multiple choice questions in a pattern. A B B A C. A B B A C.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Aw, you picked up on that huh?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How could I not?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on! There’s over 200 questions. And look at some of these things. Sheldon is to camaraderie, as the space shuttle is to blank?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There are a number of acceptable answers, for example, C: near earth transport, but certainly not B: avocado rancher. And your essay, suggesting that I’d have better luck making friends if I wait ’til the Cylons take over? Please.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hold on. I put some real work into that!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, well it’s better than what Wolowitz did. He drew a raccoon with what appears to be, a distended scrotum.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s kinda cute, until you get to the scrotum.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What hope do I have for establishing new relationships given that my current friends apparently cannot take a few hours out of their lives to help me?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I’m not going to defend a big-balled raccoon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t see how you could.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What I’m trying to say is that, maybe you can’t approach this as a purely intellectual exercise.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What do you mean!?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, remember when you tried to learn how to swim using the internet?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I did learn how to swim.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: On the floor.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The skills are transferrable. I just have no interest in going in the water.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Then why learn how to swim?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The ice caps are melting Leonard. In the future, swimming isn’t going to be optional. But you do bring up an interesting point. I don’t have to break new ground here, I’m sure much of the research already exists.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No! no, my point is, if you want to learn how to make friends, then just go out to a coffee shop or a museum. Meet people. Talk to them. Take an interest in their lives.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s insane on the face of it. Come on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Where are we going?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re driving me to the mall. I’m going to acquire a book that summarizes the current theories in the field of friendmaking.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why don’t you just lie down on the floor and swim there?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Coping with the death of a loved one. My condolences.

utterance.speaker: Woman in queue
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Family or friend?

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: Family.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Too bad. If it’d been a friend, I’m available to fill the void. It’s just as well, she smelled like moth balls.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, if you’re gonna start sniffing people, I’m gonna go get a hot pretzel.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me. Do you have any books about making friends?

utterance.speaker: Bookstore employee
utterance.content: Um, yeah but they’re all for little kids.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I assume the skills can be extrapolated and transferred.

utterance.speaker: Employee
utterance.content: Uh, I guess. They’re right over there by the wooden train set.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh! I love trains!

utterance.speaker: Employee
utterance.content: I bet you do.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (picks up train)
utterance.content: Oh my! That’s awfully sticky. Alright, let’s see. Bernie Bunny has Two Daddies Now. It’s probably about homosexual rabbits. Jerry the Gerbil and the Bullies on the Bus. Read it, not helpful. Oh! Here we go. Stu the Cockatoo is New at the Zoo. Author Sarah Carpenter lives in Fort Wayne, Indiana, with her husband and best friend Mark, and their cockatoos too. Hardly makes her an expert in making friends, wouldn’t you agree?

utterance.speaker: Little girl
utterance.content: I don’t like birds, they scare me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Me too! Most people don’t see it. What are you reading?

utterance.speaker: Girl
utterance.content: Curious George.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh I do like monkeys!

utterance.speaker: Girl
utterance.content: Curious George is a monkey.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Somewhat anthropomorphized but yes. Say, maybe sometime you and I can go see monkeys together. Would you like that?

utterance.speaker: Girl
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m making friends with this little girl. What’s your name?

utterance.speaker: Girl
utterance.content: Rebecca.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hi Rebecca, I’m your new friend, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No you’re not, let’s go.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We were really hitting it off.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Don’t look up, there’s cameras.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m curious. In the “How Well Do You Know Sheldon” section, what do you put for his favourite amino acid?

utterance.speaker: Leonard and Howard
utterance.content: Lysine.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Damn it. I had Lysine and changed it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh good! You’re just in time. I believe I’ve isolated the algorithm for making friends.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, there is no algorithm for making friends!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hear him out. If he’s really on to something, we can open a booth at Comic-Con, make a fortune.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: See, my initial approach to Kripke, had the same deficiencies as those that plagued Stu the Cockatoo, when he was new at the zoo.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Stu the cockatoo?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, he’s new at the zoo.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a terrific book. I’ve distilled its essence into a simple flowchart that would guide me through the process.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Have you thought about putting him in a crate while you’re out of the apartment?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (on phone)
utterance.content: Hello, Kripke. Yes, Sheldon Cooper here. It occurred to me you hadn’t returned any of my calls because I hadn’t offered any concrete suggestions for pursuing our friendship. Perhaps the two of us might share a meal together… I see. Well then perhaps you’d have time for a hot beverage. Popular choices include tea, coffee, cocoa… I see. No, no, no, wait. Don’t hang up yet. What about a recreational activity? I bet we share some common interests. Tell me an interest of yours. Really? On actual horses? Tell me another interest of yours. Oh no, I’m sorry, I have no desire to get in the water until I absolutely have to. Tell me another interest of yours.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh-oh, he’s stuck in an infinite loop.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I can fix it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mmhmm. Mmhmm. It’s interesting. But isn’t ventriloquism, by definition, a solo activity? Yeah? Tell me another interest of yours. Hmmm. Is there any chance you like monkeys? What is wrong with you? Everybody likes monkeys. Hang on, Kripke. A loop counter? And an escape to the least objectionable activity! Howard, that’s brilliant! I’m surprised you saw that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Gee. Why can’t Sheldon make friends?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright Kripke, that last interest strikes me as the least objectionable and I would like to propose that we do that together. Tomorrow. Yes, I’ll pay. Alright, goodbye. Alright! Time to learn rock climbing.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know, I am a fan of ventriloquism. Maybe you, me and your dummy could go get a hot beverage. He could talk while you drink.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Nope, I wanna climb some wocks.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This appears significantly more monolithic than it did on my laptop. No, one expects to see Hominids learning to use bones as weapeons.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: You afwaid of heights, Cooper?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hardly. Fear of heights is illogical. Fear of falling, on the other hand, is prudent and evolutionary. What would you say is the minimum altitude I need to achieve to cement our new-found friendship?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Come on, they have birthday parties here. Wittle kids climb this.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Little kid Hominids, perhaps. Is this your entire job? Your parents must be so proud.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Let’s go, Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Coming, Kripke. Okay. Harness seems to be secure. Small amount of incontinence just now, but the website said that’s to be expected. Hey, this isn’t so bad. A bit like vertical swimming.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Hey, look at you, Cooper. You’re almost halfway to the top.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I am? I was wrong. It IS a fear of heights.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not really. I feel somewhat like an inverse tangent function that’s approaching an asymptote.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Are you saying you’re stuck?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What part of an inverse tangent function approaching an asymptote did you not understand?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Understood all that. I’m not a mowon. Just keep going.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, I don’t think I can.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Well, then. Cwimb back down.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, that doesn’t seem any more likely.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: So what’s the pwan, Cooper?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, it’s not exactly a plan but I think I’m going to pass out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Can we please just do it one more time?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s a little thing but you really do miss it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello, everyone. I brought my new friend, Barry Kripke, home for dinner.

utterance.speaker: Together
utterance.content: Oh…

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Hewo to you, too.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How was rock climbing?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: He passed out. Just hung there like a big sawami.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: D-d-d! That’s where I sit.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Ooh, you have a special spot. What kind of wacko are you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How much time you got?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Want some Chinese food?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Tewific. Got any dental fwoss?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: In the bathroom.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Be right back. I gotta fwoss the Indian food out of my teeth if I’m gonna eat Chinese.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh yes, I pass out all the time. But, it was worth it. I’ve made substantial progress in bonding with Kripke, which brings me to an awkward moment.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s that?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Maintaining five friendships promises to be a Herculean task. So, I’m going to have to let one of you go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Me, me. Let it be me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, you are my roommate, my source of transportation and you help me fold my sheets when they come out of the dryer. You are safe.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Can I whistle?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Don’t be silly. Howard, you do not have a PhD, your cologne is an assault on the senses and you’re not available for video games during the Jewish high holidays.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Guilty as charged. I’m out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. You, too, are safe.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh come on. What do I have to do?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. You know what? I see where this is going. I’m not one of you guys. I’m not a scientist. So just…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Penny, Penny, Penny. Everything you’re saying is true, but please allow me to continue. Raj, you’re out. The good question, while you do provide a certain cultural diversity to an otherwise homogenous group, your responses to the questionnaire were truly disturbing. How could you, for a moment, think that my favourite amino acid is Glutamine?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He had Lysine but changed it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah. Shoulda, woulda coulda, Raj.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: I like to fwoss before I eat, so my gum pockets are open for new food.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Eww.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Hewo. How did I walk past you? I’m Bawy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Penny.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: Yeah, it’s not a vewy hot name. I’m gonna call your Woxanne. Ooh, pot stickers.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Suddenly I’m looking pretty good, huh?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So uh, Kripke, I was wondering if there’s any chance you could get me some time on the open science grid computer.

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No? But we’re friends!

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: I’m sowy. No, my fwiend?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m confused. I was given an understanding that you allow your friends time on the machine?

utterance.speaker: Kripke
utterance.content: No, that’s wong. There’s an official schedule. I have no contwol over it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh. This entire endeavour seems to have been an exercise in futility. Raj, you’re back in. He likes monkeys.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You gotta give him credit for sticking with it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I didn’t think he had it in him.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: He almost made it to the top this time.
